name: Bitter Oyster
description: Panellus stipticus, commonly known as the Bitter Oyster, is a small, fan-shaped fungus native to North America, Europe, and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Mycenaceae family and features small, kidney-shaped to fan-shaped fruit bodies (1-4 cm wide) that grow in overlapping clusters on decaying hardwood logs, particularly oak, birch, and beech. The caps are typically tan to brownish with a smooth or slightly velvety surface. This fungus is notable for its bioluminescence - certain strains emit a greenish glow in the dark, making it a fascinating addition to terrariums. The fruit bodies are inedible due to their extremely bitter taste. In its native habitat, it grows as a saprotroph on dead or dying hardwood trees. In terrariums or indoor settings, this fungus adds unique bioluminescent interest and helps with decomposition of wood substrates. It's popular among mycological enthusiasts for its glowing properties and distinctive appearance.
careTips: Requires decaying hardwood substrate - oak, birch, or beech logs work best
Moderate to low light - bioluminescence is best observed in darkness
Good air circulation prevents mold growth
Keep substrate consistently moist but not waterlogged
Bioluminescence may vary by strain - not all specimens glow
Fruit bodies appear in overlapping clusters
Inedible due to bitter taste - for display only
Helps decompose wood in terrarium ecosystems
